sentence-detokenized: EU rejects German call to boycott British lamb.
Peter Blackburn
BRUSSELS 1996-08-22
The European Commission said on Thursday it disagrees with German advice to avoid British lamb until scientists can establish whether mad cow disease can be transmitted to sheep.

Germany's representative on the European Union's veterinary committee, Werner Zwingmann, said on Wednesday that consumers should buy sheepmeat from countries other than the UK until scientific advice is clearer.
"We do not support such a recommendation because we see no reason for it," Nikolaus van der Pas, the Commission's chief spokesman, told a news conference.
He said that further scientific studies were needed and that if action was found to be needed, it should be taken by the European Union.

He said last month's proposal by EU Agriculture Commissioner Franz Fischler to ban sheep brain, spleen and spinal cord from the food and feed chain was a highly specific and precautionary measure to protect human health.
Fischler proposed EU-wide measures after reports from the UK and France found that sheep could contract bovine spongiform encephalopathy (BSE) - mad cow disease - under laboratory conditions.

But Fischler agreed to revise his proposal after the EU's Standing Veterinary Committee, which is made up of national animal health officials, questioned whether such action was justified because there was only a minor risk to human health.
Spanish Agriculture Minister Loyola de Palacio earlier accused Fischler at a meeting of EU agriculture ministers of causing undue alarm by "dangerous generalisations".
Only France and the UK supported Fischler's proposal.
The EU's veterinary and multidisciplinary scientific committees are due to review the issue early next month and make recommendations to senior veterinary officials.
Sheep have long been known to be susceptible to scrapie, a brain disease similar to BSE, which is thought to have been transferred to cattle via feed containing animal waste.

British farmers on Thursday denied there was any danger to human health from their sheep, but expressed concern that the German government's advice to avoid British lamb could influence consumers across Europe.
"What we need to be extremely careful about is how other countries follow Germany's example," National Farmers' Union of Wales (NFU) president John Lloyd Jones told BBC radio.

Bonn led efforts to protect public health after consumer confidence plummeted in March following a British report that suggested people could contract a disease similar to mad cow disease if they ate contaminated beef.
Germany imported 47,600 sheep from the UK last year, almost half of all imports.
It brought in 4,275 tonnes of British sheepmeat, about 10% of total imports.
The sketch of a rare Hendrix song sells for nearly $17,000.
A rare handwritten first draft of a song by American guitar legend Jimi Hendrix sold Thursday for nearly $17,000 at an auction of some of the late musician's favorite possessions.
A Florida restaurant paid £10,925 ($16,935) for the draft of "Ain't No Telling," which Hendrix wrote on a piece of London hotel stationery in late 1966.
At the end of a January 1967 concert in the English city of Nottingham, he threw the sheet of paper into the audience, where it was retrieved by a fan.
Buyers also bought 16 other items auctioned by Hendrix's ex-girlfriend, Kathy Etchingham, who lived with him from 1966 to 1969.
These include a black lacquer and pearl nacre box Hendrix used to store his drugs, which an anonymous Australian buyer bought for £5,060 ($7,845).
The guitarist died of a drug overdose in 1970 at the age of 27.
China says Taiwan is spoiling the atmosphere for talks.
BEIJING 1996-08-22
China on Thursday accused Taipei of spoiling the atmosphere for the resumption of talks in the Taiwan Strait by a visit to Ukraine by Taiwanese Vice President Lien Chan that angered Beijing.

Just hours after Chinese state media said the time was right to engage in political talks with Taiwan, Foreign Ministry spokesman Shen Guofang told Reuters, "The atmosphere needed to open talks has been disrupted by the Taiwanese authorities."
State media quoted China's chief negotiator with Taipei, Tang Shubei, as telling a group of visitors from Taiwan on Wednesday that it was time for the rivals to hold political talks.
"Now is the time for the two sides to engage in political talks...
which is to put an end to the state of hostility," Tang was quoted as saying by Thursday's edition of the People's Daily Abroad.

In an interview with Reuters television, Shen, of the foreign ministry, said he had read reports of Tang's comments but did not offer details on why the negotiator felt the time was right for talks with Taiwan, which Beijing considers a renegade province.
China, which has long opposed all of Taipei's efforts to gain greater international recognition, was angered by Taiwanese Vice President Lien's visit to Ukraine this week.
China says the time is right for talks with Taiwan.
BEIJING 1996-08-22
China has said that the time has come for political talks with Taiwan and that the rival island should take practical steps towards this goal.

Consultations should be held to determine the timing and format of the talks, the official Xinhua news agency said late Wednesday evening, citing Tang Shubei, executive vice president of the Taiwan Straits Relations Association.
Car registrations in Germany in July increased by 14.2 pct. year-on-year.
FRANKFURT 1996-08-22
German first-time car registrations rose 14.2% in July this year compared to the same period last year, the Federal Motor Vehicle Office announced Thursday.
The bureau said 356,725 new cars - 304,850 passenger cars and 15,613 trucks - were registered in July 1996.
The figures represent an increase of 13.6% for cars and a decrease of 2.2% for trucks compared to July 1995.
Motorcycle registrations increased by 32.7% during this period.
The increase was partly due to more Germans buying German cars abroad, while manufacturers said domestic demand was weak, the federal office said.
Nearly all German car manufacturers recorded increases in registrations during the period.
Volkswagen AG achieved 77,719 registrations, just over a quarter of the total.
Opel AG, together with General Motors, came second with 49,269 registrations, 16.4% of the total.
In third place was Ford with 35,563 registrations, or 11.7%.
Only Seat and Porsche had fewer registrations in July 1996 than in July last year.
Seat recorded 3,420 registrations, compared to 5,522 registrations in July last year.
Porsche registrations fell from 643 to 554.
GREEK SOCIALISTS GIVE GREEN LIGHT TO PRIME MINISTER FOR ELECTIONS.
The executive bureau of the Greek Socialist Party has given the green light to Prime Minister Costas Simitis to call early elections, the party's general secretary Costas Skandalidis told reporters.
Prime Minister Costas Simitis will make an official announcement after a government meeting on Thursday, Skandalidis said.

Israel plays down fears of war with Syria.
Colleen Siegel
JERUSALEM 1996-08-22
Israel's resigned peace negotiator with Syria said Thursday that the current tensions between the two countries seem like a storm in a teacup.
Itamar Rabinovich, who, as Israel's ambassador to Washington, has conducted unsuccessful negotiations with Syria, told Israel Radio that Damascus apparently wants to talk rather than fight.
"It seems to me that {(1)[MISC] the Syrian priority} is still to negotiate.
Syrians are confused, they're certainly tense, but the general assessment here in Washington is that this is essentially a storm in a teacup," he said.
Rabinovici ends his term as ambassador.
He will be replaced by Eliahu Ben-Elissar, a former Israeli envoy to Egypt and right-wing politician in the Likud party.
On Wednesday, Israel sent a message through Washington to Syria that it was committed to peace and willing to open negotiations without preconditions.
But he accused Damascus of creating what he called a dangerous atmosphere.
Syria on Wednesday accused Israel of launching a hysterical campaign against it after Israeli television reported that Damascus had recently tested a missile.
He said his arms purchases were made for defensive purposes.

"The message I sent to (Syrian President Hafez al-) Assad is that Israel is ready at any time, without preconditions, to enter into peace negotiations," Israeli Foreign Minister David Levy said in an interview with Israel Radio.
Tensions have risen since Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu took office in June, vowing to preserve the Golan Heights, which Israel captured from Syria in the 1967 Middle East war.
Israeli-Syrian peace negotiations have been deadlocked since 1991 over the Golan, despite the previous government's willingness to make concessions in the Golan.
Peace talks between the two sides last took place in February.
"The voices coming from Damascus are bad, not good.
Media...
are full of expressions and statements that must be worrying...
This artificial atmosphere is very dangerous because those who spread it could become its prisoners," Levy said.
"We expect Syria, if it has a face towards peace, to respond to Israel's message to enter into peace negotiations, because that is our goal," he said. "
We don't want a war, God forbid.
Nobody benefits from wars. "
Israel's Channel Two television said Damascus had sent a "calming signal" to Israel.
He did not provide a source for this report.
Spokesmen for Netanyahu and Levy said they could not confirm this.
The broadcaster also said Netanyahu sent messages to appease Syria via Cairo, the United States and Moscow.
A Polish diplomat denies that nurses are trapped in Libya.
A Polish diplomat on Thursday denied a Polish tabloid reported this week that Libya had denied exit visas to 100 Polish nurses trying to return home after working in the North African country.
"This is not true.

So far, we are not aware of any nurses being held or held in Libya against their will and we have not received any complaints," the chargé d'affaires of the Polish embassy in Tripoli, Tadeusz Awdankiewicz, told Reuters by telephone.

The Polish Labour Ministry said this week it would send a team to Libya to investigate, but Awdankiewicz said the investigation was triggered by some nurses who complained about their working conditions, such as non-payment of wages.
He said about 800 Polish nurses are working in Libya.
Two Iranian opposition leaders meet in Baghdad.
Hassan Hafidh
BAGHDAD 1996-08-22
A group of Iranian exiles based in Iraq on Thursday pledged support to Kurdish rebels in Iran after they were attacked last month by Iranian troops inside Iraq.

A statement by the Mujahideen Khalq said its leader, Massoud Rajavi, met with the secretary general of the Kurdistan Democratic Party of Iran (KDPI), Hassan Rastegar, in Baghdad on Wednesday and expressed his support for the rebel Kurds in Iran.
"Rajavi stressed that the Iranian Resistance will continue to stand by their Kurdish compatriots and the resistance movement in Iranian Kurdistan," the statement said.
A spokesman for the group said the meeting "signals a new level of cooperation between the Mujahideen Khalq and the Iranian Kurdish opposition".
In July, Iran intensively bombed targets in northern Iraq in pursuit of KDPI guerrillas based in Iraqi Kurdish areas outside Baghdad government control.
Iraqi Kurdish areas bordering Iran are under the control of guerrillas from the Iraqi Kurdish group Patriotic Union of Kurdistan (PUK).
The PUK and the Iraqi Kurdistan Democratic Party (KDP), the two main Iraqi Kurdish factions, have controlled northern Iraq since Iraqi forces were driven out of Kuwait in the 1991 Gulf War.
Clashes between the two sides erupted at the weekend in the worst fighting since last year's US-sponsored ceasefire.
Mujahideen Khalq said Iranian troops have also shelled KDP positions in the Qasri region of Suleimaniya province near the Iranian border over the past two days.
He said about 100 Iraqi Kurds were killed or wounded in the attack.
Both Iran and Turkey are mounting air and ground attacks on targets in northern Iraq in pursuit of their own Kurdish rebels.
A US-led air force in southern Turkey protects Iraqi Kurds from possible attacks by Baghdad troops.
Saudi riyal rates hold steady in quiet summer trade.
Spot rates for the Saudi riyal against the dollar and for interbank deposits in the riyal were largely stable this week amid quiet summer trade, dealers in the kingdom said.
"There have been no changes in Saudi riyal rates.
The market has been very quiet because of the summer holiday," said one dealer.
The spot riyal was placed at 3.7504/06 to the dollar.
One-month interbank deposits stood at 5-1/2, 3/8 percent, three-month at 5-5/8, 1/2 percent, and six-month at 5-3/4, 5/8 percent.
The one-year funds were at six, 5-7/8 percent.
Israel approves Arafat's flight to the West Bank.
JERUSALEM 1996-08-22
Israel on Thursday granted Palestinian President Yasser Arafat permission to fly over its territory to the West Bank, ending a brief Israeli-PLO crisis, an aide to Arafat said.
"The problem is over.
The president's plane has been given permission to pass through Israeli airspace, but the president is not expected to travel to the West Bank before Monday," Nabil Abu Rdainah told Reuters.

Arafat was due to meet former Israeli Prime Minister Shimon Peres in the West Bank city of Ramallah on Thursday, but the venue was changed to Gaza after Israel refused the Palestinian leader helicopters permission to fly.
Palestinian officials accused right-wing Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of trying to stop the Ramallah meeting by holding Arafat down.
Later, Arafat cancelled a meeting between Israeli and PLO officials on civil affairs at the Allenby Bridge, which links Jordan and the West Bank.
Abu Rdainah said Arafat decided not to fly to the West Bank on Thursday after Israel lifted the ban because he had a busy schedule in Gaza and would not be free until Monday.
Arafat to meet Peres in Gaza after flight ban.
JERUSALEM 1996-08-22

Yasser Arafat will meet Shimon Peres in Gaza on Thursday, after Palestinians said the right-wing Israeli government banned the Palestinian leader from flying to the West Bank for talks with the former prime minister.

Japanese Finance Minister Wataru Kubo told a news conference on Wednesday that he believes the Bank of Japan's (BOJ) interest rate policy, which is geared towards ensuring economic growth, has not changed since the release of the central bank's "tankan" survey.
